titlestmt.titleproper: Ford Foundation records, Correspondence with United States Senators and Representatives
A Guide to the Ford Foundation records, Correspondence with United States Senators and Representatives FA1411
titlestmt.author: Katie Martin

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2019-12-06 00:10:10 -0500.

did.unittitle: Ford Foundation records, Correspondence with United States Senators and Representatives

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The collection includes correspondence related to pending grant proposals, requests for testimony before Congress, internal Foundation memos, clippings of the Congressional Record related to Foundation issues, and acknowledgments of receipt of Ford Foundation publications.
Further information regarding the subject of the correspondence can be found in an individual folder's additional description note.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Ford Foundation was chartered by Henry and Edsel Ford in 1936 "to receive and administer funds for scientific, educational and charitable purposes, all for the public welfare", and initially served the Ford family's charitable interests in the Detroit area. Following the deaths of Edsel Ford (1943) and Henry Ford (1947), the Foundation was propelled to the forefront of philanthropy as the largest American foundation in terms of both endowment and yearly expenditures, and with an international scope to its major program areas.

During the Foundation's first twenty years its major programs were in international economic development, primary and higher education, educational and public broadcasting, behavioral sciences, civil liberties, urban development, fine arts and the humanities. The Ford Foundation also partnered with the Rockefeller Foundation in supporting agricultural development in South America, Africa, and Southeast Asia. Since the 1970s, the Foundation has also pioneered programs in women's rights, energy policy, micro-financing in under-developed countries, establishing human rights groups, and improving international HIV/AIDS education.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research with select materials restricted as noted. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: This material was transferred to RAC in 2017 by the Ford Foundation and ingested by RAC as Accession 2017:085.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Information regarding the Rockefeller Archive Center's preferred elements and forms of citation can be found at http://www.rockarch.org/research/citations.php

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged into two series:

controlaccess.subject: Ford Foundation
United States. Congress. House
United States. Congress. Senate -- History -- 20th century
